plant_translocations.content: Methiozolin, when applied via foliage, displays an absorption rate of up to 55% within the foliage itself, indicating its systemic properties. The translocation of methiozolin after foliar application reveals a predominant movement towards the upper regions of the plant (about 10% of the applied amount). Conversely, minimal translocation is observed to the lower regions of the target leaf (1.4% below the target area) and to other parts of the plant (1.3% beyond the target leaf). This upward movement suggests limited basipetal translocation and implies a lack of methiozolin movement through the phloem. Additionally, when applied to the roots, methiozolin demonstrates significant absorption but limited translocation to the foliage (less than 8 mg per gram of plant tissue) and to the crown (less than 30 mg per gram of plant tissue). This pattern aligns with its logKow value of 3.9, indicating efficient root absorption but restricted xylem movement due to low water solubility. The systemic nature of methiozolin involves moderate acropetal translocation, mainly through the xylem. This indicates that effective field application would likely necessitate exposure to both roots and foliage due to limited translocation efficiency from a singular application site, as evident from the study's results.
plant_translocations.reference: Flessner, M. L., Wehtje, G. R., & McElroy, J. S. (2013). Methiozolin Absorption and Translocation in Annual Bluegrass (Poa annua). Weed Science, 61(02), 201–208. doi:10.1614/ws-d-12-00128.1

method.Plant Grown Condition: Grown from seed in 0.7 L pots containing native soil or USGA root-zone mix in greenhouse at Auburn University. Greenhouse conditions described with temperatures below 23°C, natural daylight from Nov 2011-Apr 2012, and average 68% relative humidity.
method.Chemical preparation: Methiozolin (MRC-01) was used. In foliar and root studies, methiozolin was mixed with 14C-labeled methiozolin at a concentration of 11.98 mg/ml and radioactive concentration of 0.084 MBq/ml. In root study, concentration was 5.0 mg/ml (ppm) and 415.0 MBq/mL.
method.Received pesticide of plant: methiozolin applied to soil surface at 1.68 and 3.36 kg ai/ha. In foliar study, 14C-methiozolin droplets applied to leaves. In root study, plants in 5 ppm hydroponic solution of 14C-methiozolin.
method.Other Information: All experiments used a completely randomized design with four replications per treatment. Studies were repeated over time and data pooled for analysis.
